comment: I'm constantly telling people/family to stop buying cables from the box stores as they're just too expensive, to stop wasting their money.  As a former sales person of stereo equipment we were always told to "push new cables on new purchases", and for good reason.  I think the markup on cables and such might surpass jewelry!!  It's just horrible.  So stop buying those overpriced cables and buy them here on Amazon, or at a couple of other online retailers, for much, MUCH less.  They work just as well as the name brand cables, just without the fancy colors, or the fancy labels.  But hey, if you've got one of those unlimited budgets and money is no object, then go ahead and buy that $100+ per foot, 4 gauge speaker cable, or other severely overpriced interconnects.

2017 SepOriginally I put 5 stars, because it worked fine after installation. However about 6 months, I started to observe issue that the video image blacked out intermittently. I was not able to find the root cause, because the issue was intermittent, but recently I completely lost the image, and I identified that root cause is this HDMI cable. After I replaced the cable with another one, the image was recovered and didn't show any intermittent issue.

I am going to keep this review short and sweet. I saw many reviews referencing these cables not being able to handle 4K HDR or support 4:4:4 chroma at 60Hz. While I cannot speak for the configurations of other users, I can confirm the following:Using this cable on a Samsung KS8500, I can confirm that this cable supports:

We had bought a new TiVo and a new TV and for the lif of ours we could not pinpoint which one was malfunctioning when the sound would dip during different times of viewing.  Turns out these HDMI cables are the problem!!!! … You have no idea how much time I spent trying to troubleshoot the poor new devices.  For having put through what I have gone thru I would rate these as garbage!!! Grrrrr!!!

Amazing cables at an affordable price. Tested with 4K HDR and Dolby Vision. Works with Apple TV too. I have this HDMI cable going from my Denon AV receiver to my LG OLED TV and all my devices hooked to my AV receiver using this HDMI cable as well. Everything works great. Don't listen to the reviews that said Dolby Vision doesn't work on the Apple TV. They probably didn't set up their AV receiver and TV settings properly. The TV and the AV receiver has a setting that is listed as HDMI Deep Color or HDMI Enhanced that you will need to enable for HDR and Dolby Vision. Also it is prefered to set up the match settings under the video settings for the Apple TV.

Updating my review, I bought this 3 pack and while the first cable worked fine on 4K 60fps signals, the second and third cables has major issues.I had bought these to replace my older AmazonBasics high speed cables (10.2Gbps), however after purchasing a XBOX One X, those cables would not allow the XBOX to work in 4K. I had a similar issue with my Roku Ultra which would not work with the 4K 60fps setting. I decided to try these as they are rated at 18Gbps. While the first cable I tried worked flawlessly (no artifacts, flickering or other issues), the other two did not work as well. I tried Twisted Veins HDMI cables as well and had similar issues. I finally picked up Monoprice cables and haven't had any problems. Most people have good luck with these cables in shorter lengths (6ft or less), however at 10ft or longer I recommend looking for something else if you are using these on a 4K display. The two issues I saw with these cables at 4K 60fps were sparkles or repeating signal loss.

Please do not waste your hard earned money on overpriced HDMI cables in the name of picture or sound improvements. I currently am using these AmazonBasics High-Speed HDMI cables to connect our Yamaha v379 AV receiver to other HDMI enabled devices that link back to our 4K Samsung Smart TV and these have performed flawlessly.HDMI cables come in four types: Standard-speed --> Standard-speed with Ethernet --> High-speed --> High-speed with Ethernet. Since High-speed cables are so cheap (e.g these AmazonBasics cables), there really isn't any point of getting Standard-speed anymore. On the other hand, as most HDMI devices today can't receive Ethernet over HDMI, High-speed HDMI cables are really all you need.

I went through 3 other HDMI cables before finally just deciding to buy this one, All other 3 cables I used previously were all from other highly rated brands here on Amazon, all them claimed to support HDMI 2.0 4K @60Hz. And you can guess those claims fell flat and they did not work whatsoever, Most of those other cables would have no image to the TV when selecting HDMI 2.0 mode and also there was horrendous screen tearing eve though v-sync was enabled in the games I was playing on my PC.Well I am happy to report this is the very first cable I got that finally works as advertised. It can fully transmit a 4K 60Hz image over a 25 foot cable with no signal loss whatsoever. It even fully supports chroma 4:4:4 like a charm. This cable is an absolute beast and I cant believe how cheap it is. The other cables I got that didnt work were all over $60 and this $12 Amazon cable beats it in every way, I am a true believer in the Amazon basics brand for life now.

SO long. I never thought about how long 25 ft really was until I had it laid out in my living room! Great cable though, no issues whatsoever ever! The only concern I really have is that the cable cord is thick, a lot thicker than your standard HDMI cable. So for planning purposes this is important to note. I mounted my TV on my wall and used to cord/cable covers to maintain the wires. I was barely able to fit the TV power cable and the HDMI cord in the cover but I got it eventually. The cable works great just understand 25 ft is A LOT of cable and the cable runs a little thicker than your typical HDMI.

After reading reviews here to confirm that these cables are 4K HDR10 capable, I ordered a set of three to run in the wall between various devices and a new LG 4K tv.  They work fine with regular HD devices, but connected to an Xbox watching 4K Netflix, they fail within a few seconds every time.  It'll show a few seconds of the video, flicker to static for a second, or show noise patterns, then go blank.  Switching back to the HDMI cable that came with the Xbox works flawlessly.  All three cables exhibit this problem, so this doesn't seem to be a one-off issue.The Xbox renders all its menus and other output at 4K all the time, but the only time the cables fail is when Netflix enables HDR10 (the tv shows a little HDR badge in the corner when this happens), so I'm assuming the incompatibility is with HDR10.

When I had this cable stretched to it's 25 foot length in use it performed as described with no issues.  4K HDR @ 60 was achieved with zero issues.  I rearranged my setup and cut the distance to roughly 1/2.  Since the cable proved it's worth I simple made large loops in the cable to take up the slack and not put excessive bend strain onto the cable.  I started to get graphical glitches, cut out, and full signal lose for seconds at a time randomly.Due to the quality external construction, this is a THICK cable, I wonder if even with large loops placed in the cable it create signal interference that messed with the signal.  I usually buy cable longer than I need for changes in room furniture but due to the affordable prices and quality of the Amazon Basic cables I'd recommend trying to have multiple lengths that are the right length for your applications.

Bottom Line,  These cables do not support HDCP so you will NOT get the dialogue track, only the sound track associated with the video stream, making for some very interesting streaming of movies... LOL.I recently ordered, installed new HDMI cables to support 4K in my home theater system.  The thing about 4K is that all the devices and cables from content provider to display must be 4K compatible or the digital content drops to the least common denominator in the path.

So the video signal from my blu ray player started to occasionally break up and the player is over 6 years old so I worried it might need to be replaced.  But then I quickly though to check the hdmi cable first.  The cable being used was an AmazonBasics High-Speed cable same as this and I checked my orders and it was almost 7 years old!  Boy, that was a good amount of quality use to get from the cable.  I quickly ordered the now of course greatly updated High-Speed HDMI cable and right away blu ray player has been fine and the picture quality also improved.  I am always so thankful to get such amazing quality at such a great price.  Highly recommend this cable.

I bought 4 of these and all of them are bad. Tried using with an Xbox One X and am unable to consistently get video. Screen constantly goes black every few seconds making them basically useless.At first I thought the issue might be the Xbox or the TV (TV is brand new Samsung QLED). Ended up digging up an older (2014) AmazonBasics HDMI cable intended only for 1080p display, and surprisingly am getting 4k just fine without the screen constantly flashing off. Switching back to one of the other cables and the flashes of black immediately return, so I'm confident that these newer cables just suck.

Rip off I think the one that I have have a shortage in it maybe even used not brand new I purchase I should get a replacement for this because I have to get up and take the cord  out and place it back  in order to get a picture on the TV might have to go to the store and buy another

Unfortunately this cable did not work as advertised. I purchased the 50’ length to extend from my TV to my AVR. I require the latest tech to support  4K HDR10 signal from an X Box One S. This cable did not support HDMI 2.0 and was unable to transmit any signal from the XBox when set to 4K output. While troubleshooting I tried to hook up a 4K Roku Premium and the Roku said it was not compatible with 4K. The highest output available on the Roku using this cable was 1080.Given the specs listed on the cable, this should have worked for both the Roku and the Xbox. If it was just the Xbox being incapable of HDR10, I wouldn’t fault this cable too much. As yet The only cable I have found capable of pushing an HDR10 signal from the XBox was the one that came with the XBox. But the inability to send a 4K signal at all is inexcusable.
EXTREMELY STURDY CABLEI am pleasantly surprised by the bulk thickness of this cable, it could last longer than the items it connects.

I have an Apple TV 4K that I connected to my Onkyo receiver and then to my Sony 930 TV. The Dolby Vision was not working this route on the HDMI ARC ports (2&3). I went to best buy and got a $30 18 GB per second cable and got the same results. I had to go into the input settings of the TV and turn on the HDR there. Not in the picture settings, but the port themselves. Then, these cables with Dolby Vision and ATMOS work beautifully. See instructions belowIf you connect a device that needs to use the full HDMI bandwidth, like a UHD Blu-ray player, a video game console or a PC set to output at 4k 60p 4:2:0 10 bit, 4:4:4 or 4:2:2, you'll need to connect them via the HDMI port 2 or 3 and set the 'HDMI signal format' to 'Enhanced format', via the 'External inputs' setting pages

This is probably the most disappointed I've been in an Amazon product.  I've bought 11 of these cables, and they were fine for 4K60 HDR 10.  But I've had trouble with dolby HDR, specifically with an Apple TV 4K.  I'd also been unable to enable HDR on a Windows 10 htpc.  I spent hours troubleshooting over the months, when the only problem was these cables.  With the Apple TV I'd get random black screens and a note once, stating that my cable or TV could not support the resolution.On an Audio Video forum, I read about other people's problems similar to mine, and ended up buying monoprice premium cables.  Problem solved.  I dont know if this is a quality control issue, because these cables per their specs, should have no problems with any 4K resolution.

So I always though that HDMI cables were all the same. I was wrong. Although these cables are marked high speed they did not work in my setup. I have a Vizio M65-E0 TV, Onkyo TX-NR575 Receiver, Apple TV 4k and Xbox One S. With these cables hooked up my Xbox One S would not recognize my TV as being 4k HDR  and the Apple TV 4k would not allow Dolby Vision. The receiver can pass HDR and Dolby Vision and my TV is capable of both as well. I also had issues displaying anything from the Xbox that was not 1080p such as DVDs etc. I was very frustrated and spent hours swapping settings and resetting all my gear. I finally decided to try some different cables. I purchased the Monoprice Certified cables also available on Amazon. Voila, everything was perfect. If you are looking to get 4k HDR or Dolby Vision out of your home theater setup passing through a receiver, I would recommend you steer clear of these cables and get the Monoprice Certified. They are only a few dollars more and much higher quality.

I just bought a very nice Sony 4k television from Best Buy in Alpharetta, Ga. I bought a stand, 4k DVD player, Marantz amplifier and two HMDI 2.2 cables from the Magnolia side of the store. When i looked at my receipt later, I was amazed to see that I had paid $130 for an 8 foot HMDI cable and $100 for a 6 footer- plus 7.5% tax. The cables had silver wire in them and were supposed to deliver great sound. I have excellent hearing, and the sound quality of these inexpensive cables is almost the same. Most people would never know the difference. Satisfied? You Betcha! I returned the expensive cables and walked out with the $246 I had paid Best Buy. 3 of these cost about $12.

I've been using Amazon's HDMI cables for several years now. I use them alongside a few other brands. There's a few areas where these shine and others where they fall short.For reference, I do not have 4k so I cannot speak to how these work for 4k content/tvs.

Folks, it's an HDMI cable.  It sends a digital signal to and from the devices you connect with it.  A digital signal is all-or-nothing:  it either works as well as it can, or it doesn't work at all.  Do not be fooled by expensive cables which claim to carry a better signal:  that's just what George Carlin described as "Advertising Lullaby."  It's not worth more money from your bank account to pay for benefits that do not exist.  This cable really is every bit as good as cables which cost several times more.  No, it is.  Really.So buy this, save money, and hook up.  You'll get exactly the same image quality, and will have money left over for snacks.  Enjoy!

All three cables did not work with such devices as PS4 or Roku but found no issues with my laptop and second monitor. Will return as the primary reason for the purchase was to replace two of the three cables we have already and keep a third as a spare but since only one works with one device, might as well spend the extra money and purchase three of quality cables that will work among all devices in our household.

Roku's been around for many years making great products so I won't go too deeply into its functionality (it's awesome!) but I do want to share why I bought it and how i use it primarily.I've only owned chromecasts in the past but as part of my job, I travel very often and stay at hotels for the majority of the week. If you're not aware, hotels often require you to log into the wi-fi network typically with your name and room number and chromecasts do not support these types of logins (since it doesn't have a controllable UI - even on it's companion apps!!) so odds are you won't be able to connect chromecasts to the network.

Bought this as an amazon warehouse deal (generally a pretty good buy) and have not been disappointed.  The cable is built sturdy but not too thick that moving it around objects becomes cumbersome.  I use it to stream my Mac to my TV in order watch live streaming games etc.  What i'll say is that the mac allows the user to optimize the ouput for tv or computer, and when put on the tv setting the picture is as clear if not better than the computer. I purchased the 15 foot cable and some have indicated that at lengths over 10 feet there is distortion etc, though i have experienced none of this and there is no perceivable delay in sound or picture or quality from the cable. To note however, i'm also running it from a lightening port in the computer, through a converter to HDMI which, one would think would increase the delay and decrease the quality, though as mentioned, no issue as of yet.Five stars and highly recommended as with all amazon products

Previously I was only using the passthru hdmi on my receiver, as people were saying the tv would do better up scaling on its own. However, I tried recently and the 2160p processing from Receiver is definitely better. I am guess the tv is only doing a basic line doubling algorithm and not as good as the chipset in the Onkyo receiver. I used a thumbnail on the movie menu from Apple TV menu for The Scorch Trials. The upscaled was much less grainy and slightly brighter. After some minutes however, the picture would shake, flash and get progressively worse until I switch back to 1080p or passthru modeI tried 5 cables, all of which said there were high speed and one that said high speed with Ethernet. All failed quickly as soon as I tried 4K processing

Working as intended. ran it around the baseboards across the room. Did this so i can have my tower by me but the t.v. on the other side without having a cable to trip over. More then enough length. Cable was stiff at first from being so thick and wound so tight. it didn't seem to do any damage though and works very well, sound and video is crisp and clear.Post Statement~

I bought these cables to connect my PC (with GTX 980Ti)to my 4K TV (LG UH7700). The only color settings that work with this cable is YCbCr 420 at 8bpc. It doesn't support anything above YCbCr420 at 4k. The moment I change to 422 or 444, I get a flickering black screen with random white dots like static or something. I have confirmed it by connecting my notebook (with GTX 1070) using this cable and the issue is the same. I had another brand new shorter HDMI cable lying around which was never used so I tried that and all color settings worked like a charm. So the fault is with these AmazonBasics cable.

Purchased these to use with the apple lightening adaptor to connect the hubby' iPad to the tv.  He wanted the capability to watch Amazon, Netflix and other videos on his not smart tv and this cord and the adaptor worked perfectly.  Videos loaded immediately -much quicker than through the wifi connected blue ray player.  All we had to do was connect everything, turn o. The tv and select the source and we were up and running.  We connected the iPad to the smart tv in the living room and enjoyed watching a movie on the larger screen.  Can't beat the price for the twin pack.  I have the 2nd one plugged into the living room tv so we can quickly connect the iPad.  The 10' cable ended up being a little too short to be permanently attached to the bedroom tv - the cord was out in the open for the cat to play with.  I remedied that by ordering the 15' cable which I received today.  Hooked it up and it is out of the way!  I highly recommend these cables.  They work perfectly and you can't beat the price.

I ordered a 3 pack of the AmazonBasics “High Speed” HDMI Cables, 10 ft. Upon receiving, I plugged in my Xbox One X with the new cable, but nothing displayed. After troubleshooting, I determined it was the cable. The cable would pass 1080p signal, but when changed to 4K from the Xbox One X, it would no longer display.Of the box of 3, 1 HDMI cable properly displayed the 4K HDR content. I called Amazon and they sent me out a replacement set of 3. When I tested these 3 cables, NONE of them worked.

I purchased this cable primarily to use during a Windows 10 pro upgrade on a Windows 7 Pro Box.  It's a headless client and in day to day ops, I just RDP to it.  RDP will present some issues during the upgrade if a monitor isn't directly attached and that was my goal in getting this cable.  I tried for an hour on a known good HDMI port on my 1080 TV.  Nada.  It wouldn't pick up that anything was connected.  Figuring it might be my Windows 7 box, I updated drivers, etc. to no avail.  I then figured let me use a known good HDMI cable from my Roku, ran that to another working TV and expected it not to work as I thought the problem was my Windows 7 box but bam, instant success.  I know a lot of people have had good luck with this cable but I got a lemon.  By the way, I have purchased many great HDMI Amazon Basic cables over the years with much luck but my hope here was to get the 25 footer and then leave it run in case I ever needed to boot off USB, etc. and use my primary monitor.  Oh well.  I'm skeptical to try another after this.  Very thick and heavy cable, too, by the way.

Like a Kirkland Signature product, Amazon delivers a great product of equal value to others for cheaper.I've used all three I've bought for my PS3, Apple TV, and Amazon Fire TV. All of which are used frequently, and I've had no video or audio issues the last 4 months outputing 1080p at 60Hz.

I bought this for my mom actually. She's been wanting to watch videos from her laptop onto our new 4K TV.I bought this for $7.99 on March 29. My dad requested that I buy this using my Student trial since everywhere else sells HDMI cables of equivalent length for at least $20. 10 ft was the perfect length for them. It's long enough to extend from the coffee table to the TV.

Please be aware of how thick these are before buying! They are three times as thick as normal HDMI cords. It is not flexible near the ends and weighs a lot. It puts way too much weight and stress on the HDMI ports on your devices, breaking the port. My ports are now wobbly because of all the stress this put on them. As soon as you plug it in and let go of the cord, you can see the port and end of the cord move down a ton from the weight and stress of the inflexibility, and becomes a loose port leading to issues. Way to thick!

I purchased this cable to connect my laptop to an external monitor while creating a home workstation for the pandemic. Although it worked as advertised initially, I prefer to put my laptop away at the end of each day, which involves disconnecting the HDMI cable. Within a few weeks, I noticed that the display on my monitor was prone to strange color shifts and pixelation, which went away when I pinched or adjusted the HDMI plug at its connection to my laptop. Switching the orientation of the cable (so that I'm unplugging and replugging the other, less worn end of the cable, while leaving the delicate end in place on the monitor) helped initially, but the end with loose connections still sometimes leaves me with a weird display on the monitor. This cable should be perfectly adequate for someone who will plug it in and leave it that way (e.g. for a home entertainment system), but I wish I had spent an extra $5 for a more durable cable.

I ordered this cable because I was having some problems with another one. Well this one wouldn't even display video at 4k60hz. This could be the color depth was too high. I am not really sure why it didn't work. Amazon is vague about what HDMI standard this cable meets. Anyway, I ended up with a Syncwire cable. That was actually able to work at the specifications. This is with an Intel NUC and a Samsung TV.  I have several of these amazon basic HDMI cables. No of them would work, but switching to the Syncwire one solved everything. Syncwire specifies that it is HDMI 2.0. Maybe that is the difference.

I had my new 4k tv's installed recently, and I needed new wires capable of handling the speed and data being transferred for the best picture possible. I've read about the over-priced cable wiring, and I am guilty of purchasing those wires in the past. I have paid up to 600 dollars for an HDMI cable in the past, but it was for a true theater. However, if you aren't running very large distances, 50 or 100 feet or more, then these cables are more than sufficient to give you the highest quality picture you will get out of the tv you purchased. Most of the over-priced cables do nothing for short distance connections, since a quality cable with the required standards will give you the best possible picture, since the quality of the tv and the other equipment is the more important factor. I wouldn't trust some of the HDMI cables that come with the equipment or from the cable company, but the minor price increase you will pay for the Amazon cables is definitely worth the price and more than sufficient.

Review of High-Speed HDMI Cable, 3 Feet Length. -  When I added a new Roku Ultra 4K to our entertainment system I temporarily used my DVD player HDMI cable to test my Roku, I believe it is a 6 foot length. Well, I intermittently ran into a problem you might also encounter with the existing cable that prompted me to purchase the new 3 foot length HDMI. An error message about “HDCP” started appearing when different Roku channels were clicked on. I discovered “HDCP” stands for “High Definition Content Protection”. More than likely this error message was triggered by a loose HDMI connection.Anyway I only needed a 3 foot length HDMI, so I started looking for one on Amazon and came upon this one with highly rated reviews. We own a Samsung 4K Ultra model tv we use with our Roku, so we wanted a HDMI cable that would work in a demanding setup. After two days of use this 3 foot HDMI cable has performed great for us, no more “HDCP” error messages. And the 4K content looks great from our Roku Ultra though to our Samsung 4K tv.

Several weeks after purchase (as in too late to return it) the Wall Street Journal had a big article on counterfeit goods of all kinds and how it has become a big problem for the legitimate manufacturers.  This was one of the websites noted as experiencing a surge of counterfeit products, which I've known about and have reported to them for years.  One of the specific products they described was a cable  like this one that upon first use exploded, trashing the product (don't recall what it was).  So even though it wasn't necessarily this particular cable, I decided it wasn't worth losing my TV and have never used it.  I guess I'll have to get one from Staples.  It'll be more expensive but not as expensive as having to replace the TV.

Ordered cable to be able to use my computer monitor some distance from CPU.  I didn't realize how thick this cable was--very inflexible and doesn't fit into my cable cord floor duct protector.  But the good news is if I ever need a cable big enough to tie up a cruise ship, I'm covered

I have two issues with this Amazon Basics High-Speed HDMI Cable three pack.  One, I purchased under Amazon Prime, yet shipping was delayed.  Yeah, I know this is a minor issue but the second issue isn't.  One of the three cables is bad.  As soon as I plugged the cable in the display had pixelation.  I switched back to a known good cable and the issue was gone.  Tried a second time and the problem of pixelation returned.Normally I have good luck with Amazon Basic products, this is the first time exception. I'll contact Amazon, but I expect they will want me to return the all, two of the three are okay and being used.  Bummer.

Ordered a 25' cable to connect a PC with an NVIDIA GTX 780 to a TCL 65" 4K TV. Works great, but the plastic shield at the connector is a little on the wide side, so it *almost* didn't fit snugly into my graphics card because the metal slot is just slightly more narrow than the width of the connector. The cable itself is also incredibly thick, even thicker than standard coaxial, which I was not expecting. Not a huge deal because it makes me feel like it's much more durable than competitor's cables and it isn't too stiff so cable management is still a breeze, but the standard sized cable clips I got to run this along the baseboard were much too small so now I have to measure the diameter and get something a bit more specialized to make everything look nice and neat. No complaints on video or sound quality. Functions as expected. Great price. Would buy again.

I purchased this item for a large screen video installation at my church.  The cable was run through a conduit that was just a couple of feet short of the 50 foot length of the cable.  Unfortunately, the gentlemen pulling the cable didn't follow my instructions and had to pull it back out and redo the job to get the proper connector end at the video monitor!  PAY ATTENTION to the markings on the cable end, it could save you from a major headache!This cable (and it's 35 foot mate) is plugged into an HDMI splitter that displays the same image on both monitors which are placed on opposite sides of the front wall of our worship facility.  We have been using the system for several weeks now and we couldn't be more pleased.  The images on the monitors are crisp and true to the video source in color and in clarity.  We had no problem adjusting the monitors to the proper aspect ratio.  The images are stable with no drop-outs or artifacting.

5 months old, and already one cable has failed, surely it can't be the cable, they are new, so i checked everything else it could be, nope still no signal coming from cable box to the tv, so just for s**ts and giggles I tried another cable.... well look there, tv is receiving a signal / picture, tried the replaced cable on the dvd player, now no signal from dvd player,(yup, cable is bad) so i have 2 six foot cables and one 10 foot cable ... all Amazon Basics HDMI cables, 10 foot one was ordered to run thru the wall (project that I have not started yet) and now I won't be using the brand, could just be unlucky and I got a pi** poor made cable, but not gonna take the chance with using these on my wall project (running cables hidden) you get what you pay for, so that is my fault, Amazon does and has a lot of good things, maybe they should leave the HDMI cables to other manufacturers, I also replaced my Toslink with the Amazon brand.... fingers crossed that it doesn't die also

I purchased this Amazon Basics HDMI cable to take on vacation so we could watch movies on my MacBook Pro mirrored on the family's television.  I used an HDMI splitter I purchased here on Amazon, so I needed a second, shorter HDMI cable.  This Amazon Basics cable functioned perfectly as an HDMI cable.  It feels durable and thick.  The 3' length was perfect for my needs.Pro tip: there is no such thing as a 4K HDMI cable.  HDMI cables that were manufactured with the first HDMI devices years ago were always capable of through-putting the amount of data that 4K uses.  The devices and televisions are now catching up to the speeds that the cables were always able to do.  Don't pay extra for 4K cables or gold-plated cables.

I was moving and knocked my Wife's 32" monitor/TV off her desk; one of these cables stopped the TV from hitting a tile floor and almost certainly destroying it. The cable was bent where it connects to the TV but it did not break. It is a Samsung TV and weighs almost nothing so your mileage may vary. This cable works and works well here to replace the broken one and buy a spare; it is much cheaper to buy more than one. Highly recommended, solid 5 stars.

Great cable for the price! I was looking for a new High Speed HDMI cable for my Apple TV 4K for Dolby Vision support and this did it! Glad reports on this were right and I didn't have to spend much more. Great value and super happy it worked for me here. Don't have any hesitation about buying it, it's the real deal!UPDATE 8/27/20: I'm updating my review from a 5/5 to a 4/5. The main reason I noticed on my Apple TV  using the YouTube TV app every so often I'd get flickering. I think it was some HDMI handshake issue cause it'd lose audio when it happened, really only on the YouTube TV app. So I switched it to 50hz and it went away. I then switched the Apple TV HDMI cable I used to have hooked up to it and then set it back to 60hz and it went away. So there's definitely something going on with the Apple TV. I put this cable on my Shield TV 2019 Tube, so far so good there. I put an older version of this cable from my receiver to my TV passing the Apple TV, so good there too. So I think it's def a quirk with the Apple TV and this cable.

We recently moved, and had a lot of things cleaned out from our old place. Upon moving into our new home and hooking up our TVs, we realized we had only one HDMI cable left for the living room TV.We have a PlayStation, a Roku Premiere, and a "dumb" TV, so we had to constantly move the only one HDMI cable between two different consoles, which was inconvenient and bad for the ports. Cables can get expensive, so I looked on Amazon, and found these AmazonBasics ones.

I Exchanged these cables for my "non-ethernet" HDMI cables attached to my LG OLED TV and Comcast Box, along with Apple TV, Samsung Blu-ray 4k player, and Xbox X. attached to my Yamaha AV Receiver.  I have only one ethernet cable attached to my AV receiver and these cables were advertised to extend to other devices without needing an ethernet cable on each one.  Well, I got only static on my Blu-ray player and my Apple TV which was working perfectly the night before the exchange suddenly stopped working no matter what I plugged into it (which may be a coincidence, but...who knows?).  And as for ethernet connectivity, well, the devices attached to my AV receiver (which is wired) still only recognized connection via my WiFi network.  In summary, the cables did nothing for network speed or connection, and in at least one case (the Samsung Player) would not even work as a typical HDMI cable.

Listen to other people in the reviews.  The cords do everything all the high end cords can do at a fraction of the cost.  There is no reason to buy the more expensive versions.  They are all rated and tested to certain standards that have to be met.  The other ones are just fancier or have better name recognition.  Will standards change in the future, absolutely.  But that means the other big-brand cords will also be affected.  Do yourself a favor, these work, and work absolutely fine for what you need them to do at todays standards.  Everything seems in order.  The only knock on these is that they could have used better material (such as a braided cord to offer better wire protection), but that is all.  They transmit picture and sound just fine at a great cost.

I have a Roku 3 that flickered a lot. A googled solution suggested setting the Roku's display to 720p, which helped temporarily. For the longest time, I thought the problem was with the Roku. I googled solutions and nothing bothered suggesting something so simple... replacing the HDMI cable. I was tempted to spend a pretty penny on a good HDMI so it works and lasts because every HDMI cable on Amazon has reviews stating that the screen flickered or was black with their new cable - just the problem I'm trying to fix. I'm glad I convinced myself to give this Amazon HDMI cable a try before opting for a pricey HDMI 2.1.This cable has done away with the flickering and now I can watch my Roku in 1080p again - something I wasn't able to do as of 2 or so years ago with my previous cable. The picture and audio are great. I'll be sure to update if this cable starts to fail me.

Since the pandemic started, I've been live-streaming church services. I would hook my laptop up to the flat-screen TV as the monitor. The picture was always out of sync with the sound. It would frequently freeze up. I had to use a wireless Bluetooth speaker for the sound because the sound would not come from the TV. Lots of annoyances. I assumed it was a WiFi issue. WRONG! It was an antiquated technology issue! I was using an old USB-to-VGA cable. My computer is pretty new, and I recently realized both it and the TV had HDMI ports. So, I thought I would try a new HDMI-to-HDMI cable. I was in the middle of watching a YouTube documentary from the computer using the TV as a monitor with jerky, sound/action syncing problems when I got a notice the cable was delivered. I stopped, got the package off the porch, attached the new cable and was blown away!!! It was like watching a high-def TV broadcast show! It was never my WiFi, it was always my antiquated technology! AND, now I could also use my Bose speakers that are connected to the TV! Can't wait to watch live-stream church services now! HDMI-to-HDMI is definitely the way to go, and this cable works great!

Before buying this cable, I had to look up what Redmere was... basically its purpose is to boost signal strength over long HDMI cable runs without a secondary signal booster. There is some debate in the A/V world but 50ft is generally considered the limit of unboosted HDMI cable length without signal degradation. So the cable only works 1 way, it's not interchangeable due to the chip on one end. I have a 45' run to make so I figured for the price difference I might as well get the Redmere. Longest run I'd had previously was 25ft.The cable is nice and thick, and feels well built. I used coax staples to run the cable from a Denon home theater receiver to an Acer projector. Plugged the display end into the projector and the source end into the receiver. The projector is 1080p, not 4k, so this cable is up to task and works perfectly. I have noticed no lag or loss of signal so far.

I ordered a 25' rosewill hdmi cable from newegg, on dec 2, it didnt ship from newegg till dec 6 and scheduled to be delivered on the 14th. I was in a bit of a hurry so i turned around and ordered an amazon basic hdmi with 4k /3d, and internet support same as the rosewill cable. I received the amazon cable on dec 8th, having amazon prime helps. lesson learned order amazon whenever possible. After receiving the rosewill hdmi on the 14th i compared the 2 cables side by side for quality and size. The amazon hdmi cable was 3x the size of the rosewill cable, and quality seemed much higher in cable construction. The amazon cable looks identical to one of my expensive over priced monster hdmi cables. If you are looking for a good quality cable I would highly recommend the amazon basics hdmi cables. The price of the rosewill cable was 10.99 for 25' and amazon was 12.00 for 25' well worth the extra dollar.I have a lot of electronics hooked through my receiver 4k tv which is hooked up on the 25' amazon cable and everything works perfect.  A fyi, 25' is the limit for most receivers, I would do hdmi over cat 5, 6, or 7  if any further away.

I ordered the 25-foot cable in order to run it behind our wall and through a two-by-four so I could hook our TV up to the DirecTV box while also hiding the chords. The 25-foot chord is heavy and really thick, almost twice as thick as a standard HDMI cable. The cable also had issues reading the satellite box to the TV, but after unplugging and re-plugging a few times it eventually worked. Now that everything is setup it is working just fine, but the size of the chord did present some problems.

Hit or miss if you’re looking for 4K 60Hz Dolby Vision. I have a Vizio P65-C1 and was crushed when I just got my new 4K TV only to find out it wouldn’t accept the top 4K 60Hz Dolby Vision. I contacted Vizio and they confirmed that the TV should be able to do it, so I tried one of the other one of these cables cause I bought 2 and it did it no problem. So it’s hit or miss, one of them might be able to do full speed specs and the other might not...

This cable checks the boxes for an HDMI cable: good quality, long enough for the job, and cheap. For some reason HDMI cables continue to be more expensive than they should be, and too often devices don't come with one, even if they are sorely needed. I've been using this cable for literally years now without any issues. A great buy!

Despite having the TV for several years, I finally decided to get a second HDMI so that I wouldn't have to switch between the different consoles that I have (I don't play that often, so it doesn't come up frequently), so I didn't want anything very expensive.  I was dismayed at the prices of the selection at Brick and Mortars, which were in some cases 5 times the cost of this.  What I got surprised me, plugs on the ends, nice thick cabling, works great for a budget price.

I've known over the years to just find an HDMI cable and use it. Price doesn't really matter since HDMI has a standard, and all HDMI cables have to adhere to that standard. The only major issue with price is the material quality, which still shouldn't matter, as it's a cable that gets plugged in and sits, mostly without movement unless you're doing a specific thing with the cable.I had been using an Apple TV 4k for some time and after I bought my first 4k TV, I noticed the video quality wasn't the greatest, and I know 4k was supposed to look incredible. The straw that broke the camels back was when I took one of the HDMI cables I owned and plugged my new PC into my 4k TV to play some Bioshock Remastered. Noticed the game only ran at 30 FPS and 4k didn't look so great. I figured this was due to my old cable being HDMI 2.0, and decided to go shopping for new HDMI cables.

This is an awesome HDMI cable. I got it to connect my 50" Toshiba fire tv to my PC (Pic 3) I was afraid that the length (15') would diminish the quality of the video, but nope! It looks awesome. Extremely clear HD quality with movies and especially my gaming. The graphics look insane! I have an Invidia GeForce gtx 750 Ti 2gb video card and it does its job.The cable itself is pretty damn thick! (Pic 2) I put the penny there to show you how thick it is. I like it. It seems like it'll last a pretty long time. Of course it'll be stationary, It won't be moved at all.

This Amazon HDMI cable is one of the many very reasonably priced 'AmazonBasics' products available here on this website.HDMI cables (and really any cables, in general) have long been subject to the claims made by some sellers that their (much more expensive) cables were higher quality, faster, and so forth. In fact, any HDMI cable that satisfies requirements for high speed 4K video will work just as well as any other.

I have bought a number of these, maybe 9 or so. They seem to always fail. I've had to rewire my entertainment system many times to root out which cable is dead, nearly always it's one of these. It has to do with the "handshake" that HDMI uses. I get an active signal, but no picture /sound, or an intermittent flash off and on of the signal. I do not advocate buying expensive HDMI cables, just not these. Go to monoprice.com for cheap cables. Luckily, I keep a handful of HDMI on hand for rewiring, I'll never buy these again. Just spent 2 hours swapping cables tonight after 12 hours on my feet working retail... Amazon, get a better supplier, these are not good.

Three stars due purely to inconsistency in quality. Ordered one pair, and one of the cables works (and the other doesn’t) when hooked up to sources using HDR10. Both cables work fine if hooked up to sources not requiring this much bandwidth. Still super cheap if you don’t mind the potential waste of some being to full spec and some not. The cable that works looks and sounds great. No discernible video or audio issues, though it may take longer to complete initial HDCP handshake than my previous cables (I think... could be mis-remembering and I’m not going to check) even though it will complete the handshake.I will be trying a different brand for my next purchase as I am looking for cables that work with HDR10 sources and I do mind the waste.

received this in July 2018, it was the SLOWEST device to connect and navigating menu option was painful, but I just decided to deal with it. However when friends come over they don't miss the opportunity to laugh at how slow it is. 6 months later it will not connect to wireless network at all. Run diagnostics, reset connection, unplug/plug device even restart modem and routers wireless if fine for every other device, but this one will not connect. This thing is junk save your money and yourself a lot of frustration.

Didn’t work with Apple TV 4K.Only audio was playing on be Netflix app and I could see the subtitles but no video. Even  the pause button was not working. It shows the error message “this video can’t be played. It looks like your HDMI cable or connection doesn’t support HDCP, which is required to play this type of video. Try reconnecting the HDMI cable from Apple TV to your TV, and play this video again.”

This is a fine cable along the lines of all the other mega thick cables out there.  The trouble is, thicker jackets do not equate to higher quality.  Thinner jackets work just as well and are much less aggravating to work with.  The thick jacket and heavy duty plug prevent this cable from fitting into the pocket in the back of my Vizio M Series TV or next to any other HDMI cable in an adjacent socket on my Sony ES receiver.Here is the naked truth about HDMI cables: they either work or they don't, and there is no such thing as a premium passive cable.  There are only 3 possible outcomes with any given HDMI cable:

I really dont ever give one star feedback on an item and Amazon basics products have been really great for me in all other circumstances. This HDMI cable might work for some electronics that dont require superior quality cable for HD or 4K monitors and TVs. I bought this one because it was shown as "frequently purchase with" add on for an HD monitor I bought to use with my HP laptop as a second screen. It worked for two days and stopped after that. I wish I could have known it was the brand new cable right away...but I looked at reviews on the monitor and saw people blaming the problem on the cheap monitor from Acer....or people thought it wasnt compatible with windows 10. All you get is a message that your computer won't detect the monitor. I tried windows updates...rolling back display drivers, updating drivers, flushing bios,  HP tech help, Acer Tech help....in the end after trying everything else I was about to throw the monitor away and get an HP monitor...expecting that since all my other devices were HP...it would work. Then as I was about to order it I was also going to get the HP HDMI cable. I decided to try just the new cable first. Two days later I got the cable...plugged it in....Bob's your uncle...it worked just fine! In fact the picture quality was even better than before.

Bought this one (25ft version) about a year ago for the first time, it worked quite well for a few months of heavy use before I stopped using it when I moved my gaming PC closer to my 4K TV so I opted to go with a shorter one that I have. Recently, I changed my gaming PC setup again, so I needed my 25ft cable back in business. The one I got about a year ago started having a problem with intermittent signal. I'm pretty sure it wasn't either my PC nor my TV since they still work all right with the shorter HDMI cable.That said, I decided to buy another one and just got it today. It turned out the new one got this problem from day-1.  It's even worse than the old one as the intermittent signal occurs more frequently with the new cable. Needless to say, I will have to return it tomorrow, first thing in the morning.

I bought this to hook a laptop up to the conference room TV at work.  The longer length allowed me to set the laptop on the conference room table even with the TV across the isle.  The picture quality was good and so was the sound.  Overall the cable appeared to be good quality upon visual inspection and I like the gold plated HDMI connectors on either end.The only reason I subtracted one star was because upon initially connecting the laptop to the TV there is a slight pop on the TV speakers and the picture shutters a bit.  Once it connects; however, everything is fine.  Not sure if it is the TV, the laptop or the cable, but the TV is a Samsung and the laptop a Dell, so I'm assuming it the cable.  However, for the price, I can't complain.

IF YOU ARE READING THIS, TRUST ME AND JUST BUY THESE. I ASSURE YOU THEY ARE THE BEST!High quality product at a fraction of the cost from Best Buy. I have been buying a lot of Amazon Basic equipment and have yet to be disappointed! Now I actually prefer to buy Amazon basic equipment.

I've purchased 3 of these in the past couple of years,  Only 1 seems to be able to pass 4k 60Hz signal reliably.  The latest one I got absolutely would not provide my Samsung ku6300 tv with 4k 60Hz 4:4:4 signal from my GTX 1050 and appears to struggle doing this at 30Hz, another did but had artifacts on the screen, and the other (the oldest, incidentally) appears to work correctly.  All can do 4k 30Hz 4:2:0.  I got a refund for the latest one and Amazon didn't ask me to send it back, so props for that, but after this experience I'll try spending a little more next time.

NOT COMPATIBLE WITH UHD 4K HDR!Do not buy this cable if you’re looking to pass full 60hz 4k video to your tv. The connection will be choppy and will cut in and out. Initially I thought it was my BLU Ray player. I swapped it for a new one and still had issues so I swapped the hdmi cable with a hdmi 2.0 cable that I also purchased from amazon and it worked fine! 😡

Does what is should, it works with HDR and the latest proprietary version of HDMI...If I could give a zero star for HDMI proprietary "handshakes" then I would. I absolutely hate this newest rendition of HDMI handshake protocol... every so often I have to change up HDMI ports because the handshake fails. Or I have to power cycle the device. This is over multiple devices... but this cable... it works. Don't blame it for HDMI propriety handshakes failing.

I had bought these to replace my older AmazonBasics high speed cables (10.2Gbps), however after purchasing a XBOX One X, those cables would not allow the XBOX to work in 4K. I had a similar issue with my Roku Ultra which would not work with the 4K 60fps setting. I decided to try these as they are rated at 18Gbps. While the first cable I tried worked flawlessly (no artifacts, flickering or other issues), the other two did not work as well. I tried Twisted Veins HDMI cables as well and had similar issues. I finally picked up Monoprice cables and haven't had any problems. Most people have good luck with these cables in shorter lengths (6ft or less), however at 10ft or longer I recommend looking for something else if you are using these on a 4K display. The two issues I saw with these cables at 4K 60fps were sparkles or repeating signal loss.

I was excited by the reviews on this cable and seen it looked like a good quality cable. I was soon disappointed. First, I didn't pay attention and accidentally bought the 25 ft in stead of the 6 ft, so more cable then i needed, which was my fault. I had a big problem with it. When i hooked it to my Shield TV streaming device i could not get it to work. Just a black screen. A few times i got the home screen for about a minute and then it blacked out again. I even tried different ports on my OLED TV just in case but still got the same black screen. I switched out the monster cable from my JBL soundbar to the Shield TV  and it worked perfectly. I switched the Amazon cable to my sound bar and it worked just fine. I can't figure out why it would work for the soundbar and not the Shield TV. Does anyone have any ideas? The Shield TV is 4k so it just doesn't make any sense why it wouldn't not work.

Ordered these because I started working from home and the the cables that the monitor came with left a weird glare when connected to my laptop, one of my friends suggested I order a Hdmi cable, the first one i received didn't work and I couldn't understand why, I had the right input, everything was plugged in. I unplugged the monitor and used the old cable that the monitor came with and it worked fine so it wasn't my monitor... I was unplugging and plugging and changing settings for a good half an hour before i decided it was the cable. Contacted the seller and just received the new cables in the mail and let me tell you these are the best few bucks i've ever spent. It sure beats ruining my eyes and paying for glasses down the line. 6ft was a little too long but they didn't have 3 feet available. I am just glad it worked!

I like the performance - don't like the unwieldy Jacket.The cable itself is good with good secure connectors but the jacket makes getting this to bend around obstacles and lay flat difficult.  I compare this to a very similar HDMI cable - same  thickness - but with a woven nylon outer Jacket. The woven nylon lays much flatter and makes bends easier to achieve and not resisting your intented layout.

So essentially, these will give you a 4k video, but does not support HDR and Dolby Vision.  I have a 2018 LG OLED with a Yamaha RX-A780 receiver and 4K will not run HDR/Dolby Vision with 4:4:4.  So, if you are using an AppleTV 4k or PS4 Pro or pretty much anything that will deliver HDR and/or Dolby Vision.  These unfortunately will not work.  18Gbps does not matter if they do not support the rest.  Hope this helps some people!!!

I have always had great experiences with Amazon products except these. They didn’t work at all. Tried on Xbox AND my computer. No luck. Put the old HDMI back on and back in business. Oh well. On a positive note they refunded me immediately with no complaints. That is fantastic. No harm no foul. I’d buy again since they treated me so well.

Didn't even last 3 months run from my projector to my source switch. This cable was run in the ceiling and walls to an HDMI plate in the wall where there is zero movement. One day it decides that it doesn't want to work anymore and transmits picture with tons of artifacts. Maybe I got a dud? Past the return window anyway; is there an amazon Basics warranty?

The cable worked great in the eARC HDMI link from recievier to 4K UHD TV.  Picture was excellent and expected controls and audio was there over the eARC interface.  The contacts have a thin gold vaporized surface to aid connectivity.  The strain relief is welded or glued to the cable and cannot be twisted off the cable.  The cable itself is very pliable and easily routed in a bundle of other cables.

I was using the only HDMI cable I had laying around at the time which happened to be a 10ft HDMI cable that I have had for several years now. The monitor (external to my laptop) would not wake up from sleep. Otherwise it worked great once I manually woke it up with the button. This 3ft cable solved that issue and is a lot neater since it is short.

Why are cables so expensive? Because it's the last mile and without it, your wonderful TV, speakers, phone, and other electronics will not work without it! That's why I like Amazon Basic electronic products. It fills a hole in the market place and they have produced affordable and quality electronic cables. In the past I used to buy all of my electronic cables from Monoprice but since I have Amazon Prime and the quality of the electronic cables are good, I have purchased an iPhone charging cable and this HDMI cable to connect a PS3 and my laptop to the TV.

It took me longer than it should have to get this cable, but once I got it, I couldn't have been more pleased. I didn't realize it was a combination HDMI/Ethernet cable, so it's considerably thicker than your standard cable. I don't have a current use for the Ethernet functionality, but I'm glad I have it should I have need of it in the future. I needed a long HDMI to connect the ARC port of my Roku TV to my home theatre received, located some distance away. It does everything it's supposed to do, enabling machine control from the TV the receiver and carrying the audio. I have always bought Amazon Basics HDMI cables because the ones in the big box stores are priced outrageously, and I have never been disappointed. With this most recent purchase, that continues to be the case. Buy without fear. This is the good stuff.

Was happy at first, then tv stopped working.  cable provider sent tech out couldn't find problem so he blamed it on the tv manufacturer.  1 month later Tv people diagnose bad HDMI cable.  purchased new one, works great.  with closer inspection this Amazon basic should be renamed to basic garbage.  Don't waste your money.

These cables are REALLY thick. I bought 2 to feed these though PVC pipe in my walls to a media closet. Only one would fit and took up so much space, it was hard to get the other wiring back in. If you are looking to run these through the PVC that runs through your walls, which based on the length, these would appear to be meant to do just that, you may have problems.

Works well. I did a lot of research on different HDMI cables and brands before I purchased this one. Seems to me there isn't much of a performance difference - if any - between cables like these from Amazon Basics compared to the rather expensive ones. Ideally, the main thing you'd want to be sure of is you get a High-Speed HDMI cable, which is exactly what this is. And of-course, one that is constructed properly.I decided to get the pack of two because the price difference compared to just the one makes it a logical decision. Also, in that case I have a backup.

I upgraded an Apple TV 2nd Gen with a refurbished 4K model.  Initially I did not replace the HDMI cable since it was working fine with the old Apple TV.  When using the Apple TV 4K the image was spotty/pixelated, the connection was lost every few seconds and an HDCP error would be displayed every now and then.I initially thought the refurbished Apple TV 4K was faulty but decided to search Google and try a few recommended fixes.  A number of articles advertised using certified HDMI cables to guarantee the quality of sound and picture.

I tested my cables out, to be on the safe side, to see if they'd work on my spare TV and Blu-ray player, should my originals conk out, and they work just as great as big brand HDMI cables! Now I won't have to demand a refund, even though they almost arrived over 30 days after ordering them!

Okay was not expecting this cable to be this thick. Its higher around than my pinkie. That being said. It is a great cable. I've been using it with my gaming systems (ps4/switch) and the video/sound quality is excellent. My bf and I play on tvs sitting right next to each other and my picture quality is 100x better. The colors are more vibrant and the sound it just crazy better. Before the quality was about the same.

When I first got this, i was so excited! I thought it was worth the money and it worked perfectly. Unfortunately after less than a month, it just stopped working. I tried to see if it was just the device I was using but it wasn’t, I tried it with other devices... and still a no go. I didn’t even have it bent or anything. So I’m a bit confused as to why it stopped working...

I've tried pretty much every combination of source/TV I have, but I continue to get no signal through these cables (I'm on my second set) when using any hardware that outputs a 4K signal.My 4K hardware consists of a Sony UHD Blu-Ray player, a Roku Ultra Box, and X-Box One S. When cables are attached to any of these devices and connected to EITHER a 4K television or a 1080P-only set, no signal is transmitted. When the cables are connected to a regular Blu-Ray player (both a Sony and LG) or a non-4K streaming box (WDTV Live), the signal passes through. It also passes through an old Acer Revo Windows PC. But 4K? Not on your life. My previously purchased cables from Monoprice work just fine with all the hardware mentioned above.

So after trying about four or five other 25 feet HDMI cables, including a couple of high quality Monoprice ones and a few from Amazon, this is the only 25 feet HDMI cable that was able to properly carry a 4K signal from my PC to my TV at 60 hz and 4:4:4 chroma as well as 4:2:2 10-bit HDR. Even the active HDMI cable I got from Monoprice had artifact issues and was not able to carry a stable signal at 25 feet.It's kinda funny how a $13 cable was able to outperform cables that cost like 2-3x or more. Though looking at how thick the cable is, I'm not surprised that it was able to perform as well as it has. I just wish I had bought this cable before wasting money on those other cables.

This is about the 10 feet cables; maybe the shorter cables are ok...Quality of cables is insufficiënt to carry 4K input over 10 feet; PlayStation 4 pro crackling sound, Sonos sound bar cuts out every 10 minutes and Verizon tv box cuts sound (although very rarely but it’s not a 4K device).

I've replaced my monitor, which had VGA and DVI ports and a DVI-to-HDMI cord connecting it to my computer. My new monitor has HDMI and VGA ports, and I ordered this cable ONLY because it didn't cost significantly more than a VGA-to-HDMI cable or adapter would have. Besides, how MUCH of a difference would it really make? Well, here's my answer: WOW!!!I've read that HDMI enhances the audio as well as video signal, but this is like going from tuna fish to caviar! My monitor's HD resolution now resembles what I'm used to seeing only in electronics departments and sports bars. But it's what I'm hearing that's really blowing me away: the warm, natural, vinyl analog sound I grew up with has been reborn, and my twenty-dollar computer speakers now sound like I paid five times as much! If you have HDMI sockets on your computer and monitor that you aren't using, stop making the same mistake that I nearly did!

After 10 months one screen started goring off (no signal) intermittently the after a week it went off permanently. One month later the second Display to HDMI cable started displaying the same symptoms. I tried them on different monitors and different computers but still receiving 'no signal'. Now, my computer can see there is a monitor connected (even the brand) but the monitors receives no image. The cables are..well were in a permanent position, never moved for the entire year. The issue seems to be in the circuitry in the cable rather than a loose connection. The cable started 'blacking out' then went dark eventually.So if you want a quick fix or for a one-off job buy them but if you want to plug-in and forget it look elsewhere.

This HDMI cable is like a garden hose. It’s seriously thick. Way bigger than I expected. But it works great for connecting my PS4 up to a monitor 25’ away. Great picture, no lag or signal disruption, and as thick as the cable is, I don’t have to worry about the cable weakening or breaking over time as I roll and unroll the cable often to use when gaming.UPDATE 01/24/2020 - I ultimately had to replace this cable with another brand. I recently purchased a brand new LG UltraGear 4K HDR gaming monitor, and for some reason this cable was not passing along an HDR signal. Switching to other cables I had worked fine, but switching back to this cable did not. My PS4 Pro would indicate that the connected display did not support HDR while this cable was in use. I ended up purchasing another 25' HDMI cable of a different brand, and that cable works without issue, fully supporting HDR.

The cable seems nice and sturdy; well built.  I have no issues with it in that regard.  I was disappointed that it wasn't able to allow my monitor to run at 144hz.  In fact it wouldn't even run at the 75hz the stock cable could.  60hz was max.  I had to use a display port cable to reach the 144hz.  However, I will keep this cable for any upcoming needs for high resolution as it seems to be a very nice cable for television use with HDR and 4k.

For us, there's a point of diminishing returns when it comes to cable quality. We have a 32" LED TV with a very nice picture... we don't expect to be blown away by the experience or immersed in VR by our video entertainment, so the very nice picture is plenty fine. These cables seem to reliably carry enough information between our devices to give us that nice picture no matter which device we're using. They're flexible, connect solidly and feel like we could plug and unplug them more times than the devices would probably hold up to. The cables and equipment are not on display, not trophies. They're all and more than we need in a cable. We don't need bling, just entertainment!

I purchased this to connect a new, very basic 19" Insignia TV to a cable box. Unbeknownst to me, some TVs require an HDMI/ethernet cable, so this standard HDMI cable did not work. This was also a surprise to the Xfinity installer, who happened to have the right cable on hand. Lesson learned: A standard HDMI cable does not necessarily work for all TVs. Amazon gave me a refund, but it would be nice if the description of this product noted that it may not work for all TVs.

Tried to save a little money and use this cable with my 144 hz Aorus monitor. From time to time I would see streaks flashing horizontally across the monitor. Did all the usual things; troubleshoot the monitor, make sure I had the most recent drivers for my GPU, tried tweeking the overclocking on the GPU, etc. It kept getting worse. Finally I unplugged the HDMI cable and plugged it back in and shazzam problem disappeared, mostly. It still comes back and reseating the cable makes it go away. Even the orientation of the cable as in it exits the GPU or the monitor a little to the right or left makes a difference. So I am replacing it with a higher quality cable. So I basically wasted the $7

These cables do not consistently work with the Apple TV 4K with Dolby Vision enabled on my brand new 55" LG OLED B8.  I bought three of them to replace an old Insignia HDMI cable that was not rated for HDMI 2.0.  The new cables needed to be routed through my entertainment system which is time consuming.  It wasn't until after I'd routed the cables that I discovered through a great deal of testing that only 1 of the 3 cables functioned with Dolby Vision enabled on my Apple TV 4K.  The funny part is the old Insignia cable that was not rated for Dolby Vision 4K worked flawlessly with the Apple TV 4K in Dolby Vision mode.  I should have never replaced the Insignia cable!  These cables seem fine for regular 4K and I'm leaving them in since it's too much hassle to replace them in the install and send them back.  It's unlikely that I'll need more than 1 Dolby Vision enabled device in the future, thankfully.  Don't buy if you're using an Apple TV 4K in Dolby Vision mode, some of them do work but it's not worth gambling on these.

These cables are thick and long and don't bend easily. They are also a bit unwieldy. Thankfully I have cable tie and was able to subdue these beasts. If you need long and tough cables this is what you should get. If you don't and you need flexibility, these may not be the choice for you.

Normally when you buy a device that has an HDMI port you get a cable to connect it to whatever you're going to watch it on. I recently needed to buy an HDMI switcher to connect two devices to a single HDMI jack on my dumb telly, except it didn't come with a cable to connect it to my telly. I only needed a short length to connect them, and this cable is actually longer than I need, but it's doing the job beautifully. If you only need a short HDMI cable don't discount this one just because it comes from Amazon. I've bought several AmazonBasics products and they're all better than what would I expect from a big box store brand item.

I just bought a LG 65C8 OLED TV with a 10-bit Display, Model number: OLED65C8PUA...,  A week ago, And I have been on the hunt for a HDMI cable that will support, 4K Ultra HD, Dolby Vision®, Dolby Atmos, Advanced HDR, HDR10, HLG @ 18Gbps..After buying and trying a couple of different High Speed HDMI cable's here at Amazon, Including this one... Not one, Has worked without having Audio drop out's...

Once upon a time I fell for the cable hype. I overpaid for MONSTER cable (about 15 years ago) and found that ultimately, you don't have to spend a fortune to get good quality performance from your cables. Yes, maybe if you're a serious video-audiophile, you might perceive some fleeting nuance differences... but 95% of us aren't like that. I use this cable primarily for feeding video from my laptop to my old SONY XBR LCD TV. Picture quality looks pretty much 1080p to my eyes. And the cable is thick where it counts. Cheap HDMI cables will eventually cause wire fraying at the plug joints, forcing you to buy more cables. This cable feels robust enough such that this won't happen. I'll report back in a year.

I didn't notice this in the product description on the webpage "This is NOT a bi-directional cable, display connector is marked with a monitor logo".  And thinking it was a bi-directional cable (like most HDMI cables are) I installed it without paying attention to the "Display" label at one end.  Unfortunately for me the cable Display end is not where the display actually is.  And cable is run through a crawlspace and into a wall.My fault for not reading the details (could be highlighted to make sure customers see it).  Will take some work but I can uninstall and reverse it.

I recently had to replaced my 2008 Denon receiver after sudden death with a 2018 Pioneer model. For some reason the image from my Tivo was pixelated and I traced the issue to the HDMI cable. It seems that the Denon did a better job than the Pioneer at handling this quality issue. So I ordered the AmazonBasics HDMI cable and, not only did it take care of the problem, it significantly improved the overall quality of the image: crispier, better color. I'm very happy with this cable and I ordered more to replace other older HDMI cables.

other than the fact that they are cheap, you will NOT notice any lag difference when watching TV or movies compared to other "high speed" cables. for gaming on the other hand, when you test these (which i did not do because it does not bother me too much) there might be a difference in response time versus gaming HMDI cables with quicker response times. but overall, these are great for the average consumer!

Great 4K cables but these shouldn’t be called high speed from amazonbasics. They aren’t when it comes to technology now. The ones I received  wouldn’t go over 9gbs. Whenever 18+ is what is necessary for atmos and 4K together.  I would say that these are the best bang for your buck though when it comes to cheap 4K needs like just plugging into a tv with no high end hdr or color pitch. Also- if you have a need for enhanced sound passed 5.1 surround- I would also stay into the 18gb+ range.A small tip...  stay away from Samsung tv’s if you want Dolby Atmos unless you want to buy a decent splitter and three decent $20 cables.

Noting that there already are thousands of reviews and most are positive, I'm going to keep this short and sweet.I needed a high-speed, three-foot long, HDMI for my Fire TV Cube. I didn't want to take a chance by trying to save any money, so I went straight for this AmazonBasics.

The Amazon Basics High-Speed HDMI cable is a good cable at a very good price.  I recently replaced my stereo receiver and upgraded to all-HDMI connections between the components using these cables.  They are high-speed and handle 4K video from the Amazon Fire TV device to the receiver and then to the 4K TV without any problems.  Video from the other components (CD/DVD/BR player, Cable TV box) works equally well over these cables.Tip:  You might need a longer cable than you realize.  I thought 3-foot cables would be fine, but once I started running them I realized there wasn't any slack left to pull components out of the cabinet etc, so 6-foot cables were the better choice.

Amazon Basics makes some good cost effective products. No need for a more expensive name brand cable. No problems watching movies with 4K Dolby Vision on a Roku Premiere connected to my Samsung 4K TV. I've bought Amazon Basics batteries and LED bulbs that also work just as well as a name brand alternative. All at a cheaper price, of course. Glad to see they are coming out with more and more produces as time goes on.

I bought this and it worked great on my tv and ps4 for a couple of days. Yesterday I was going to play ps4 and the signal wouldn’t show on my tv. I took the hdmi cable out of the ps4 and hooked it up with my laptop and tv and was not able to see anything either. I went and bought a new one at Walmart and it worked on my laptop, but not the ps4. I looked more closely with a flashlight and my ps4 HDMI port had a small thin stick stuck to it. I looked at the bad HDMI cable and it had a small piece break off, the one inside my ps4 HDMI port. So now, I can’t play my ps4 because of this cheap piece of garbage...

My TV signal has been flickering in and out intermittently for weeks.  I assumed it was my cable provider, but decided to try a different HDMI cable first.  Turns out this brand new cable was faulty.  I have requested a replacement, we'll see how the next one is.Update: Amazon sent me a replacement cable.  It worked for 2 hours, and then the flickering started up again.  I switched out the cable for another HDMI cable (an older Amazon Basics model) and it worked fine.  This latest model of cable seems to be defective.

Nice and long - but this is has a much thicker jacket than other HDMI cables I've gotten.  We run this from the TV to the laptop and the heavy jacket means it does not uncoil well or lay cleanly under the throw rug.  If you're using this for a temporary hookup - say running it across a stage or your living room floor like us, it might not be the cable for you as the jacket is stiff.  Still, it works.

This HDMI cable does its job admirably. Please don't buy into the hype of fancy gold plated, Kevlar coated cables like Monster and the like. Any high speed HDMI cable will carry a 4K signal and a $60 cable will work the same as a $10 one. They might have better build quality or use nicer materials but their job is to carry a signal and any cable will do that about the same as another. This Amazon Basics cable is a great value and feels like it will last a long time. I've had it connecting my PS4 to my 4K TV for more than a year and have had zero problems to speak of. If you need an HDMI cable and want to save a little money to put towards a better soundbar or TV instead of a fancy $50 cable then this one will work just fine.
Nice quality cable. It was a thick design which comes in handy since this cable is most likely going to run a long distance. Didn't really notice and quality drop on my gaming.5 stars when working.
I got this cable for occasionally projecting my laptop screen onto my Sony Bravia TV, which doesn't have a very smooth screen mirroring feature.I project for

I used this because my smart TV quit being so smart after a lightening strike. I was in a pinch because the final season of GoT was coming on in a week and my TV refused to stream anything or accept streaming from my computer. My choice was to buy a whole new smart TV or to buy this reasonably priced cable. I got it in the 25 ft option, so I wouldn't have to drill a hole in the wall between the computer room and living room. One of my tech-savvy buddies said to buy the cheapest HDMI cable, because buying an expensive one was a waste of money (they don't have a better picture or sound). He was right. This one gave us a perfect quality video and sound and was very easy to use. Pro tip: disconnect your speakers on your computer to get the sound to travel to your TV.

I'm a big fan of Amazon cables and batteries so the last thing I decided to try when my brand new Amazon Fire box didn't work out of the box was swap my brand new Amazon HDMI cable with a different brand and then "wa-la" it worked perfectly. I tried this cable with my laptop and a different (Samsung) TV which worked fine so the cable is not DOA, it's just something weird about the Fire box and my TV which doesn't seem to be an issue with my other cable. Reading other comments it seems like these cables sometimes have issues. Very disappointed that I can't rely on the Amazon brand.

Problem solved. I have another Amazon basics cable running through my wall to a mounted TV. I bought a new TV stand and needed to extend the cable to reach my AV receiver. I went through 2x other extension cords and 2x couplers that all claimed to be 4k ready, but it turned out they could only pass through a signal at 4K if at 30fps or less. That's fine for a lot of streaming devices that output 4k at only 30fps but if you have a home theater PC or want to be future ready, it won't cut it.This cable was the only one that I found capable of extending a full 4k60fps signal without artifacts. Bravo Amazon. Great product.

I originally really liked these cables but after more real world testing with 4K@60hz 4:4:4 they've come to disappoint. You might get away with using this if you have a single short run direct from device to TV. In my case, a PS4 Pro to LG OLED C8. It would give occasional partial snow on the screen that would flash. But, very occasional and worked most of the time. Once I ran through the receiver it became far less reliable and I had to switch cables entirely. My receiver does support pass-through for this format.Most people won't experience this unless you're using a PS4 Pro or PC that wants to send 4:4:4.

I thought this was an upgrade from Amazon's older HDMI cables but, I don't think so... This cable does not fully utilize the ARC (Audio Return Channel) capabilities; it will only transmit the power function and not any other control functions. Okay, this is only a basic cable but I have gotten other $5.00 cables which handle all ARC functions.Overall, this is a decent basic HDMI cable which delivers a clear HD picture. Plus, these cables appear well made.
When using comcast dta cable boxSuddenly no signal switched to different hdmi input same problem

I work in the field of video entertainment and as long as the HDMI cables are clearly labelled High-Speed they should be good for 4K @ 60Hz. Should be. These were for about a month, then they stopped my 4K Blu-ray from linking up to my TV. The trouble shooting that followed drove me, Sony and I dare say TCL absolutely mad. It turned out to be the cable. So, while I still use one between my cable box and TV and that works fine, I cannot recommend them for a genuine 4K application. Buyer beware - you shouldn't pay the exorbitant prices of say a Best Buy HDMI cable, but you should be prepared to part with more than $10.

I am using this between a projector and a 4K Apple TV.  This cable worked okay when connected to a Nintendo Switch (720p) or to a BlueRay player (1080p); however when connected to the Apple TV, the projector displays "No Signal" or "Not Supported."I spent 30-60 minutes trying to figure out why the Apple TV wouldn't come up.  I even tried reversing the cable as I remember some longer HDMI cables are unidirectional - same results.  You would think the Apple TV would fall back to 1080p if it couldn't negotiate a 4K signal (but it didn't, not with this cable anyways).  This was very frustrating.  If I use a different cable between my 4K Apple TV and projector, it works fine.

These cables are perfect!!  I purchased one a while ago, and recently purchased two more. I have more expensive cables with gold tips on multiple TVs in the house, but found that because the HDMI ports on my TVs require them to be plugged in horizontally instead of vertically, the more expensive thicker and heavier cables  that I had would droop and lose connection briefly at times (very annoying if you are watching football!).
